description: From Middle English depressen, from Old French depresser, from Latin dēpressus, perfect participle of dēprimō (“to press down, to weigh down”), from dē- (“off, away, down, out”) +‎ premō (“to press”).

verbs.description: depress (third-person singular simple present depresses, present participle depressing, simple past and past participle depressed)

examples: Depress the upper lever to start the machine.

entries.meaning: To make depressed, sad or bored.
(economics) To cause a depression or a decrease in parts of the economy.
examples: Lower productivity will eventually depress wages.

entries.meaning: To bring down or humble; to abase (pride, etc.).
(mathematics) To reduce (an equation) in a lower degree.
